conclusion: Setup with four containers at the top labeled A, B, C, and D releasing liquids of different colors.
Two containers at the bottom, E and F, need to determine which container the liquids will flow into.
Baffles are obstacles or dividers that direct the flow of liquids.
Initial image shows liquids being directed by baffles towards either E or F.
Second image shows liquids interacting with each other and baffles creating branching or merging paths.
Yellow liquid from A flows downward and possibly mixes with others.
Light blue from B, pink from C, and dark blue from D flow downward and interact similarly.
Third image shows more defined paths with branches leading towards E and F.
Yellow and light blue seem to direct more towards E.
Pink and dark blue might be going towards F.
Trace the path of each liquid from top containers to bottom containers considering baffles.
Container A (yellow) is positioned on the left top corner.
Baffle directly below A angles the liquid flow towards the left.
Yellow liquid might be directed towards the left side of the bottom containers.
Container B (light blue) is next to A on the top.
Baffle below B directs the flow downward and possibly towards the left.
Light blue liquid might be directed towards the left side of the bottom containers.
Container C (pink) is next to B on the top.
Baffle below C directs the flow downward and slightly towards the right.
Pink liquid might be headed towards the right side of the bottom containers.
Container D (dark blue) is on the far right top.
